0Ruby#,Ruby#,Generate a random string in ruby of length / generate password,"(0...32).map{ [('a'..'z').to_a,('A'..'Z').to_a,(0..9).to_a].flatten[rand(62)] }.join"

42UNIX#,UNIX#,Find the number of fields/number of columsn/ number of tabs in a line,cat /tmp/delme.txt |  egrep -o -E $'\t' | wc -l  == wc -l /tmp/delme.txt * cat /tmp/delme.txt | head -1 |  egrep -o -E $'\t' | wc -l

84UNIX#,UNIX#,Unix signal SIGINT Ctrl-C,"The SIGINT signal is sent to a process by its controlling terminal when a user wishes to interrupt the process. This is typically initiated by pressing Control-C, but on some systems, the ""delete"" character or ""break"" key can be used.[3]"

85UNIX#,UNIX#,Unix signal SIGTERM,"The SIGTERM signal is sent to a process to request its termination. Unlike the SIGKILL signal, it can be caught and interpreted or ignored by the process. This allows the process to perform nice termination releasing resources and saving state if appropriate. It should be noted that SIGINT is nearly identical to SIGTERM."

86UNIX#,UNIX#,Unix signal SIGKILL,"The SIGKILL signal is sent to a process to cause it to terminate immediately (kill). In contrast to SIGTERM and SIGINT, this signal cannot be caught or ignored, and the receiving process cannot perform any clean-up upon receiving this signal."
87UNIX#,UNIX#,Unix signal SIGQUIT Ctrl-D,The SIGQUIT signal is sent to a process by its controlling terminal when the user requests that the process quit and perform a core dump.

88UNIX#,UNIX#,Unix signal SIGHUP,"The SIGHUP signal is sent to a process when its controlling terminal is closed. It was originally designed to notify the process of a serial line drop (a hangup). In modern systems, this signal usually means that the controlling pseudo or virtual terminal has been closed.[2]"

89UNIX#,UNIX#,Unix signal SIGSTP Ctrl-Z,"Suspends a process. This too, can be handled, ignored or blocked. Since it does not terminate the process, the process can be resumed by sending a SIGCONT signal. This signal can be generated by pressing Ctrl+Z. (Sidenote: Ctrl+Z stands for substitute character which indicates End-of-File in DOS)"

175GIT#,GIT#,git remove a file from the index (will undo addition to the index),git reset HEAD <file>
176GIT#,GIT#,git show commits with abbreviated hash,"git log --pretty=format:""%h %an %s"""
177GIT#,GIT#,git show commits for a branch,git log --first-parent --no-merges
178GIT#,GIT#,git log show file names that have been modified,git log --name-status

182GIT#,GIT#,Git ammend a previous commmit,git commit --amend
183GIT#,GIT#,Git remote add a new upstream,git remote add upstream yourrepo.git
184GIT#,GIT#,Git branches,https://github.com/Kunena/Kunena-2.0/wiki/Create-a-new-branch-with-git-and-manage-branches
185GIT#,GIT#,Git create a branch,git branch name_of_branch
186GIT#,GIT#,Git rename a branch,git branch -m old_branch new_branch

192GIT#,GIT#,Git do a diff with a particular branch,git difftool somebranch:UNREADME otherbranch:README
193GIT#,GIT#,Git diff with a previous commit,git diff 5cdfs6ed HEAD index.html
194GIT#,GIT#,Git reset to head,git reset --hard HEAD
195GIT#,GIT#,Git checkout previous commit,git checkout 1dcf2d
196GIT#,GIT#,Git undo changes to a file not staged for commit,git checkout -- filename
197GIT#,GIT#,Git merge branch to master,git merge branchname

199GIT#,GIT#,Git Create branch,git branch branchname
200GIT#,GIT#,Git Remove a branch from local,git branch -D branchname

202GIT#,GIT#,Git reset to a previous state,git reset --hard to reset to a previous state. Use the git-reflog command to find the SHA-1 of the previous state and then reset to it.
203GIT#,GIT#,Git merge only certain files from a separate branch,git checkout branchname pathtofile1 pathtofile2
204GIT#,GIT#,Git revert to a previous commit,http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4114095/git-revert-to-previous-commit-how

210GIT#,GIT#,TO apply your changes,git stash --apply
